Border Gateway Protocol 4 (BGP-4) Send Hold Timer Border Gateway Protocol 4 (BGP-4) Send Hold Timer
draft-spaghetti-idr-bgp-sendholdtimer-07 draft-spaghetti-idr-bgp-sendholdtimer-08
Abstract Abstract
This document defines the SendHoldTimer session attribute for the This document defines the SendHoldTimer session attribute for the
Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) Finite State Machine (FSM). Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) Finite State Machine (FSM).
Implementation of a SendHoldTimer should help overcome situations Implementation of a SendHoldTimer should help overcome situations
where BGP sessions are not terminated after it has become detectable where BGP sessions are not terminated after it has become detectable
for the local system that the remote system is not processing BGP for the local system that the remote system is not processing BGP
messages. For robustness, this document specifies that the local messages. For robustness, this document specifies that the local
system should close BGP connections and not solely rely on the remote system should close BGP connections and not solely rely on the remote
system for session closure when BGP timers have expired. This system for session closure when BGP timers have expired. This
document updates RFC4271. document updates RFC4271.

"SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and

14 [RFC2119] [RFC8174] when, and only when, they appear in all 14 [RFC2119] [RFC8174] when, and only when, they appear in all
capitals, as shown here. capitals, as shown here.

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
This document defines the SendHoldTimer session attribute for the This document defines the SendHoldTimer session attribute for the
Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) [RFC4271] Finite State Machine (FSM) Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) [RFC4271] Finite State Machine (FSM)
defined in section 8. defined in section 8.
Failure to terminate a 'stuck' BGP session can result in Denial Of Failure to terminate a 'stuck' BGP session can result in Denial Of
Service, the subsequent failure to generate and deliver BGP WITHDRAW Service, the subsequent failure to generate and deliver BGP WITHDRAW
messages to other BGP peers of the local system is detrimental to all messages to other BGP peers of the local system is detrimental to all
participants of the inter-domain routing system. This phenomena is participants of the inter-domain routing system. This phenomena is
theorised to have contributed to IP traffic backholing events in theorised to have contributed to IP traffic backholing events in
global Internet routing system [bgpzombies]. global Internet routing system [bgpzombies].
This specification intends to improve this situation by requiring This specification intends to improve this situation by requiring
sessions to be terminated if the local system has detected that the sessions to be terminated if the local system has detected that the
remote system cannot possibly have received any BGP messages for the remote system cannot possibly have received any BGP messages for the
duration of the SendHoldTimer. Through codification of the duration of the SendHoldTimer. Through codification of the
aforementioned requirement, operators will benefit from consistent aforementioned requirement, operators will benefit from consistent
behavior across different BGP implementations. behavior across different BGP implementations.
BGP speakers following this specification do not exclusively rely on BGP speakers following this specification do not exclusively rely on
remote systems robustly closing connections, but will also locally remote systems robustly closing connections, but will also locally
close connections. close connections.
2. Example of a problematic scenario 2. Example of a problematic scenario
In implementations lacking the concept of a SendHoldTimer, a In implementations lacking the concept of a SendHoldTimer, a
malfunctioning or overwhelmed remote peer may cause data on the BGP malfunctioning or overwhelmed remote peer may cause data on the BGP
socket in the local system to accumulate ad infinitum. This could socket in the local system to accumulate ad infinitum. This could
result in forwarding failure and traffic loss, as the overwhelmed result in forwarding failure and traffic loss, as the overwhelmed
peer continues to utilize stale routes. An example fault state: as peer continues to utilize stale routes.
BGP runs over TCP [RFC0793] it is possible for hosts in the
ESTABLISHED state to encounter a BGP peer that is advertising a TCP
Receive Window (RCV.WND) of size zero, this 0 window prevents the
local system from sending KEEPALIVE, CEASE, WITHDRAW, UPDATE, or any
other critical BGP messages across the network socket to the remote
peer. Historically, many BGP implementations were unable to handle
this situation in a robust fashion. Previous BGP RFC specifications
would not give cause for the session to be torn down in such
situations.
An example fault state: as BGP runs over TCP [RFC9293] it is possible
for hosts in the ESTABLISHED state to encounter a BGP peer that is
advertising a TCP Receive Window (RCV.WND) of size zero, this 0
window prevents the local system from sending KEEPALIVE, CEASE,
WITHDRAW, UPDATE, or any other critical BGP messages across the
network socket to the remote peer. Historically, many BGP
implementations were unable to handle this situation in a robust
fashion. Previous BGP RFC specifications would not give cause for
the session to be torn down in such situations.
Generally BGP implementation have no visibility into lower-layer Generally BGP implementation have no visibility into lower-layer
subsystems such as TCP or the peer's current Receive Window. subsystems such as TCP or the peer's current Receive Window.
Therefore, this document relies upon BGP implementations having the Therefore, this document relies upon BGP implementations having the
ability to detect whether the TCP socket to a BGP peer is progressing ability to detect whether the TCP socket to a BGP peer is progressing
(data is being transmitted), or persisting in a stalled state. (data is being transmitted), or persisting in a stalled state.
3. Specification of the Send Hold Timer 3. Specification of the Send Hold Timer
BGP speakers are implemented following a conceptual model "BGP Finite BGP speakers are implemented following a conceptual model "BGP Finite
State Machine" (FSM), which is outlined in section 8 of [RFC4271]. State Machine" (FSM), which is outlined in section 8 of [RFC4271].
This specification updates the BGP FSM as following: This specification updates the BGP FSM as following:
3.1. Session Attributes 3.1. Session Attributes
The following mandatory session attributes are added to paragraph 6 The following mandatory session attributes are added to paragraph 6
of Section 8, before "The state session attribute indicates the of Section 8, before "The state session attribute indicates the
current state of the BGP FSM": current state of the BGP FSM":
9) SendHoldTimer 9) SendHoldTimer
10) SendHoldTime (an initial value of 8 minutes is recommended) 10) SendHoldTime (an initial value of 8 minutes is recommended)
3.2. SendHoldTimer_Expires Event Definition 3.2. SendHoldTimer_Expires Event Definition
Section 8.1.3 [RFC4271] is extended as following: Section 8.1.3 [RFC4271] is extended as following:
Event XX: SendHoldTimer_Expires Event XX: SendHoldTimer_Expires
Definition : An event generated when the SendHoldTimer expires. Definition : An event generated when the SendHoldTimer expires.
Status: Mandatory Status: Mandatory
If the SendHoldTimer_Expires (Event XX), the local system: If the SendHoldTimer_Expires (Event XX), the local system:
- logs a message with the BGP Error Notification Code "Send Hold - logs a message with the BGP Error Notification Code "Send Hold
Timer Expired", Timer Expired",
- releases all BGP resources, - releases all BGP resources,
- sets the ConnectRetryTimer to zero, - sets the ConnectRetryTimer to zero,
- drops the TCP connection, - drops the TCP connection,
- increments the ConnectRetryCounter, - increments the ConnectRetryCounter,
- (optionally) performs peer oscillation damping if the - (optionally) performs peer oscillation damping if the
DampPeerOscillations attribute is set to TRUE, and DampPeerOscillations attribute is set to TRUE, and
- changes its state to Idle. - changes its state to Idle.
If the DelayOpenTimer_Expires event (Event 12) occurs in the Connect If the DelayOpenTimer_Expires event (Event 12) occurs in the Connect
state, the local system: state, the local system:
- sends an OPEN message to its peer, - sends an OPEN message to its peer,
- sets the HoldTimer to a large value, and - sets the HoldTimer to a large value, and
- sets the SendHoldTimer to a large value, and - sets the SendHoldTimer to a large value, and
- changes its state to OpenSent. - changes its state to OpenSent.
If the DelayOpen attribute is set to FALSE, the local system: If the DelayOpen attribute is set to FALSE, the local system:
- stops the ConnectRetryTimer (if running) and sets the - stops the ConnectRetryTimer (if running) and sets the
ConnectRetryTimer to zero, ConnectRetryTimer to zero,
- completes BGP initialization - completes BGP initialization
- sends an OPEN message to its peer, - sends an OPEN message to its peer,
- sets the HoldTimer to a large value, and - sets the HoldTimer to a large value, and
- sets the SendHoldTimer to a large value, and - sets the SendHoldTimer to a large value, and
- changes its state to OpenSent. - changes its state to OpenSent.
A HoldTimer value of 4 minutes is suggested. A HoldTimer value of 4 minutes is suggested.
A SendHoldTimer value of 8 minutes is suggested. A SendHoldTimer value of 8 minutes is suggested.
4. Send Hold Timer Expired Error Handling 4. Send Hold Timer Expired Error Handling
If a system does not send successive KEEPALIVE, UPDATE, and/or If a system does not send successive KEEPALIVE, UPDATE, and/or
NOTIFICATION messages within the period specified in the Send Hold NOTIFICATION messages within the period specified in the Send Hold
Time, then the BGP connection is closed and a log message is emitted. Time, then the BGP connection is closed and a log message is emitted.
5. Operational Considerations 5. Operational Considerations
When the local system recognizes a remote peer is not processing any When the local system recognizes a remote peer is not processing any
BGP messages for the duration of the Send Hold Timer, the local BGP messages for the duration of the Send Hold Timer, the local
system will not be able to inform the remote peer through a BGP system will not be able to inform the remote peer through a BGP
message as to why the session is being closed (i.e. a NOTIFICATION message as to why the session is being closed (i.e. a NOTIFICATION
message with the "Send Hold Timer Expired" error code). message with the "Send Hold Timer Expired" error code).
Even so, BGP speakers SHOULD provide this reason as part of their Even so, BGP speakers SHOULD provide this reason as part of their
operational state; e.g. bgpPeerLastError in the BGP MIB [RFC4273]. operational state; e.g. bgpPeerLastError in the BGP MIB [RFC4273].
6. Security Considerations 6. Security Considerations
This specification addresses the vulnerability of a BGP speaker to a This specification addresses the vulnerability of a BGP speaker to a
potential attack whereby a BGP peer can pretend to be unable to potential attack whereby a BGP peer can pretend to be unable to
process BGP messages and in doing so create a scenario where the process BGP messages and in doing so create a scenario where the
local system is poisoned with stale routing information. local system is poisoned with stale routing information.
There are three detrimental aspects to the problem of not robustly There are three detrimental aspects to the problem of not robustly
handling 'stuck' peers: handling 'stuck' peers:
* Failure to send BGP messages to a peer implies the peer is * Failure to send BGP messages to a peer implies the peer is
operating based on stale routing information. operating based on stale routing information.
* Failure to disconnect from a 'stuck' peer hinders the local * Failure to disconnect from a 'stuck' peer hinders the local
system's ability to construct a non-stale local Routing system's ability to construct a non-stale local Routing
Information Base (RIB). Information Base (RIB).
* Failure to disconnect from a 'stuck' peer hinders the local * Failure to disconnect from a 'stuck' peer hinders the local
system's ability to inform other BGP peers with current network system's ability to inform other BGP peers with current network
reachability information. reachability information.
In other respects, this specification does not change BGP's security In other respects, this specification does not change BGP's security
characteristics. characteristics.
7. IANA Considerations 7. IANA Considerations
This document requests IANA to assign a value named "Send Hold Timer This document requests IANA to assign a value named "Send Hold Timer
Expired" in the "BGP Error (Notification) Codes" sub-registry under Expired" in the "BGP Error (Notification) Codes" sub-registry under
the "Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) Parameters" registry. the "Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) Parameters" registry.
